subject: RE: [junit] testing for compile errors
msgSnippet: Dear Jon, Could you fork a process, run javac, and parse the output? Alternatively, if you are running under Eclipse, you could just try to create an instance
messageBody:
Dear Jon,

Could you fork a process, run javac, and parse the output? Alternatively, if
you are running under Eclipse, you could just try to create an instance of
the class that shouldn't compile:

public class WithCompileError {
asdf
}

Then you can test it to make sure the correct error is thrown:

public class CompileErrorTest {
@Test public void classWithError() {
try {
new WithCompileError();
} catch (Error e) {
assertTrue(e.getMessage().contains("Unresolved
compilation problem"));
}
}
}

(I'm not a big fan of checking error messages, but here it seems to make
sense). The limitation I see with this approach is that each class with an
error each needs to be in its own file.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> A while back I posted a question/suggestion about being able
> to test for
> compile-time erros. Such testing is especially important in the
> presence of java generics -- you want to be sure that some
> data types,
> such as in method parameters, compile correctly, but others
> result in a
> compile error. Testing these cases by hand defeats the whole
> purpose of
> unit testing.
>
> Is there any way to test for a compile time error in a JUnit
> test? Is
> this something that would be impossible to add?
>
